Subject: Techraking <=10: Bootstrapping the News (Sponsored by The Center for Investigative Reporting)
Description: Speakers: Michael Corey, Aaron Williams, Eric Sagara - Give us four hours and your laptop, and we’ll send you into NICAR with a fully-functioning data-crunching machine and the knowledge to use it. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1695/

Subject: Secrets of Covering Money (Sponsored by the Donald W. Reynolds National Center for Business Journalism)
Description: Speakers: Brandon Quester - Money is in every story, from education to politics to metro, sports and entertainment. Learn how to explore the money across many beats in this pre-conference Reynolds Center workshop led by Brandon Quester.  | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1694/

Subject: Welcome and overview of the conference
Description: Speakers: Jaimi Dowdell, Alex Richards, Megan Luther, Mark Horvit - Welcome to the conference! IRE staff will highlight key sessions and events that you won't want to miss while in Atlanta. We'll also give you a brief rundown on some of the resources IRE has to offer. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1698/

Subject: Spotlight: Being a reporter when everyone's a journalist and there's data everywhere
Description: Speakers: Zeynep Tufekci | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1697/

Subject: Getting started: Intro to CAR and the conference
Description: Speakers: Megan Luther, Ron Nixon, Jill Riepenhoff - Are you new to data journalism or does this happen to be your first time at a CAR conference? Is it time to up your game but you're not sure how to take the next step? If so, this session will help you get on track to make sure that you get the best experience possible from the 2015 CAR Conference. We'll highlight sessions and give you tips for success during and after the conference. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1699/

Subject: Excel magic (advanced functions)
Description: Speakers: MaryJo Webster - Learn about various tools and functions in Excel that come in handy when you need to re-structure or otherwise get your data ready for analysis. We'll cover string functions, logical functions, date functions, the Tableau Reshaper, merging data using lookup functions and perhaps a few other nifty tricks if time allows. This is a fast-paced class intended to introduce you to these tools, not master them. But you'll walk out with practice data and a 20-page tipsheet that covers in detail everything we do in class, plus other great Excel tips. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1616/

Subject: Investigating caretakers
Description: Speakers: Robert Benincasa, Jeff Kelly Lowenstein | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1809/

Subject: Interactive data graphics in Tableau Public (Hosted by Tableau)
Description: Speakers: Ben Jones - Learn how to create beautiful, interactive data visualizations on short deadlines. No programming required. You'll learn everything you need to build data visualizations and publish them to your website just like a video.  | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1607/

Subject: Deep dives part 1
Description: Speakers: Mark Horvit - *Moderated by Mark Horvit, IRE/NICAR | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1724/

Subject: Map Camp (pre-registered attendees only)
Description: Speakers: David Herzog, Jennifer LaFleur, Robby Deming, Brian Peterson - Learn how to uncover interesting news stories by mapping data with geographic information system (GIS) software during our intensive mini-boot camp and receive a free copy of ArcGIS Desktop*. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1598/

Subject: Getting started with open-source database manager MySQL
Description: Speakers: T. Christian Miller - Plenty of data these days come in large or relational tables that require a good database manager, beyond what Excel and even Access can offer. MySQL is a free, powerful, and popular open-source tool, and with it you can transform and analyze almost any dataset. In this class we will introduce you to MySQL and how it works. Please note that we cannot help you install it here, but there'll be plenty of help for that at the installation party Sunday at 9 a.m. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1791/

Subject: Intermediate/Advanced Python
Description: Speakers: Jeremy Bowers, Serdar Tumgoren - You've written a few Python scripts that get the job done, but the initial euphoria has worn off. Your code is hard to understand. Bugs are cropping up. Worse, you can't always explain your process or results to an editor -- or yourself. There must be a better way, but the path forward is not clear. If you've had that itchy feeling, this daylong, hands-on workshop is for you. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1600/

Subject: PyCAR
Description: Speakers: Chris Keller, Ryan Murphy, Katie Park, Kevin Schaul, Heather Billings, Tom Meagher, Alex Richards, Eric Sagara - Introduction to Python. This hands-on workshop will teach journalists basic programming concepts using the Python language. The daylong class will introduce language basics and useful libraries in the course of a typical reporting project: scraping data from the Web, inserting it in a database and analyzing the results. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1599/
Location: See printed schedule for room information

Subject: Twitter tricks and analytics
Description: Speakers: Doug Haddix - If you know the basics of Twitter, you're ready to ratchet up your skills. This hands-on session will take you to the next level: advanced Twitter searches, mining tweets by location, creative uses of Twitter lists (public and private), and apps/services that provide robust analytics. The payoff: better sources (particularly during breaking news) and a competitive edge in your market. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1792/

Subject: From words to pictures: Text analysis and visualization
Description: Speakers: Nicholas Diakopoulos - You've got a massive pile of text: some Ferguson tweets, a box of now OCRed documents, or maybe a corpus of press releases you scraped. How do you make sense of it? In this session I'll introduce some alternatives for using text visualization to see your texts in different ways. Then I'll talk about some of the machinery for text analysis that you'll need to get there, with pointers out to Python tools. Next year you'll be visualizing the SOTU like a pro. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1700/

Subject: Make Photoshop work for you
Description: Speakers: Christopher Canipe | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1617/

Subject: The forgotten history of data journalism
Description: Speakers: Scott Klein - You may think that data journalism started in the 1960s, but the truth is, data's been a central part of journalism since its very beginning. You'll see beautiful examples of data visualizations in news from the 18th and 19th centuries, and a data-backed investigation--complete with nerd box--from before the Civil War. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1701/

Subject: Tracking diseases
Description: Speakers: Gary Baum, Daniel Lathrop, Betsy McKay | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1702/

Subject: Designing database applications to increase page views and ad revenues
Description: Speakers: Edward Garcia - With journalists facing increasing pressure to create data interactives that engage more readers, it’s important to optimize data-driven applications for interactivity, traffic and page views. Learn how to design and deploy revenue-generating applications that will continue to serve as long-lasting data assets. This demo will showcase real-world examples and techniques for building “share-worthy” hyper-local applications. Technologies covered: Caspio, Google maps, Google charts, GPS and location proximity, AJAX, CDN, data feeds, SEO, and cross-channel deployment (web, mobile and social). | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1711/

Subject: Excel for business and economics
Description: Speakers: Aaron Kessler - ​Whether you just started using Excel or it's been your companion for years, chances are there's a lot it can do you've never realized. We sometimes think of Excel as the stepping stone to database managers like Access or SQL Server, and overlook just how powerful its tools can be. Especially if you're covering business and economics, come find out why Excel is still so popular in the business world and we'll unlock some of its secrets. The people you're covering know these tricks - you should too. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1611/

Subject: Do it once (and only once)
Description: Speakers: Derek Willis, | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1703/

Subject: Interactives without programming: A new tool for building data-driven, interactive content
Description: Speakers: Ted Benson | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1705/

Subject: What the hell is R and all the other questions you’re afraid to ask
Description: Speakers: Sisi Wei, Tisha Thompson - Ever wondered what people are talking about at this conference? What exactly is R and why you would want to use it? What is the difference between Ruby, Python and Javascript? And why is there a J in front of Query? Welcome to our no-judgment-starting-at-step-zero session even NICAR vets can use. We'll review tech concepts and jargon you'll likely hear at NICAR this year, explain what they mean, why they're useful and point you to the sessions that can teach you the terms you now understand. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1704/

Subject: Advanced design and interaction in Tableau Public (Hosted by Tableau)
Description: Speakers: Jewel Loree - Analyzing data and coming up interactive visualizations is easy in Tableau but sometimes getting everything looking polished isn’t. In this session you will learn how to break away from the default formatting in Tableau Public to create interactive data graphics that match your style guides and engage your readers.  | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1608/

Subject: Spotlight: A conversation with Hanna Wallach - lessons from computational social sciences
Description: Speakers: Sarah Cohen, Hanna Wallach - **Moderated by Sarah Cohen, The New York Times | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1709/

Subject: OpenRefine
Description: Speakers: Frederick Kaimann | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1612/

Subject: Tell stories about your community with real estate data
Description: Speakers: Skylar Olsen - Housing data is about more than just real estate. Get beyond the market reports and tell stories about your community: Watchdog government programs, profile up-and-coming neighborhoods, and inform your daily reports on transit, crime, and new development. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1710/

Subject: First steps with R
Description: Speakers: Annie Waldman - Take your first steps with powerful, open-source statistical language R by learning some of the basic skills you need to get up and running with R. By the end of this session, you will be able to take raw data, import it into R, and start your analysis. Topics that will be covered include: basic data importing, working with directories, reading in data, installing packages, as well as how to clean, explore and sort data. We'll also talk about how to find help when you're stuck. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1793/

Subject: Getting started with Access
Description: Speakers: Pam Dempsey | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1618/

Subject: Uncovering racial and economic divides using data
Description: Speakers: Tim Henderson, Malik Singleton, David Herzog, Nikole Hannah-Jones - *Moderated by Malik Singleton, New York University | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1706/

Subject: Data from scratch: When data don't exist
Description: Speakers: Ricardo Brom, Griff Palmer, Lisa Pickoff-White - You've got a great story idea but no one tracks the data. Time to quit, right? Wrong. We'll show you the tools, and the pitfalls, of making your own data when no data exists. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1707/

Subject: Digging deeper with the Web
Description: Speakers: Jaimi Dowdell | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1708/

Subject: Intro to data stories in Tableau Public (Hosted by Tableau Public)
Description: Speakers: Andrew Cheung - Got a dataset and an impending deadline to write a story on it? Find the scoop and convey it with beautiful, interactive visualizations in a serial narrative using Tableau Public. It’s a fast, easy to use, and free tool for journalists. Visualizations will publish using any CMS and no programming is required.  | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1609/

Subject: Plotly: Making & sharing beautiful, engaging graphs
Description: Speakers: Matthew Sundquist - Plotly allows you to create beautiful, interactive graphs and data visualizations in your browser. Use the same JavaScript library the New York Times uses (d3.js) and embed your graphs in blogs, websites, & articles. But you don't need to code to make beautiful, interactive graphs; while you can use Python, R, and more to make graphs, you can also make graphs with Excel, Google Drive, and by copying and pasting data into a grid. It's collaborative, free, and entirely online. In this talk, we'll talk about graphing best practices and look at how The Washington Post, Wired, The Guardian and others use Plotly graphs in their work. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1716/

Subject: The latest on open records
Description: Speakers: Michael Morisy, Jackie Kazil, Kathleen Johnston, Tom Clyde - *Moderated by Kathleen Johnston, independent journalist | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1715/

Subject: Space journalism: Using satellite imagery for data projects
Description: Speakers: Brian Jacobs, Lela Prashad, Derek Watkins, Al Shaw | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1714/

Subject: CAR on the beat
Description: Speakers: Kate Martin, Christopher Weaver, Jennifer Smith Richards - *Moderated by Jennifer Smith Richards, The Columbus Dispatch | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1712/

Subject: Stats: An introduction
Description: Speakers: Jeff Kelly Lowenstein | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1613/

Subject: Make every international story a data story
Description: Speakers: Eva Constantaras, Giannina Segnini - Some international headlines just won't stop. There's endless fighting in Ukraine.  So, let’s find out where are those weapons are coming from.  Greece may default on its loans unless it reforms its tax system. We can calculate how many Greek citizens actually pay taxes. Nigeria’s elections are plagued by corruption. Let’s have a look at the how much was being transferred to politicians from Swiss bank accounts.   With a dearth of quality international news coverage, a little bit of data can transform breaking news on the crisis of the week into in-depth coverage that leads to greater accountability.  This session will dissect some of the biggest international investigations of the year, the data behind them and their global and local impact. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1713/

Subject: Grabbing data from websites without scraping
Description: Speakers: Scott Klein, Michelle Minkoff | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1627/

Subject: Counting and summing with Access
Description: Speakers: Andrea Fuller | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1619/

Subject: Stats: Basic linear regression
Description: Speakers: Holly Hacker | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1614/

Subject: Analyzing jobs in your community
Description: Speakers: Tyler Dukes, MaryJo Webster, David Hiles - Learn about various data sources, both federally and locally, that can help you look at the changing makeup of jobs in your community. What's growing? What's declining? What's expected in the next 5 to 10 years? Also learn about ways to watchdog local and state programs that are promising to create jobs. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1717/

Subject: Bedfellows: Explore the relationships between PAC donors and recipients
Description: Speakers: Derek Willis - Come learn about Bedfellows, a new tool developed for analyzing federal campaign finance data. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1721/

Subject: Import.io: Web scraping without coding
Description: Speakers: Andrew Fogg - import.io allows you to convert data from the internet into a structured useable table. This data can then be used to analyze trends, build leads and build news stories. Extracting data gives you ultimate control. The class centers around extracting data from the web followed by manipulating and using that data. We will use import.io to gather the data and then use 3rd programs (Google Sheets and Excel) to manipulate and use the data. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1655/

Subject: Humanizing numbers
Description: Speakers: Ryan Gabrielson, Katie Park, Ron Nixon, Nikole Hannah-Jones - *Moderated by Ron Nixon, The New York Times | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1719/

Subject: Data journalism in the university: Making the paradigm shift
Description: Speakers: Meredith Broussard, Matthew Waite, Brant Houston - *Moderated by Brant Houston, University of Illinois | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1728/

Subject: Joining tables with Access
Description: Speakers: Michael Pell | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1620/

Subject: I screwed up. I survived and you can, too.
Description: Speakers: Sarah Cohen, Tom McGinty, Coulter Jones, John Perry - *Moderated by Coulter Jones, MedPage Today | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1718/

Subject: Advanced calculations and analysis in Tableau Public (Hosted by Tableau Public)
Description: Speakers: Tara Walker - Learn how to use Tableau to dive deeper into your data and ask powerful questions. We’ll be starting with a “messy” dataset and learn how to explore trends that would normally be difficult to see without further analysis and calculations.  | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1610/

Subject: Teaching data journalism: Your best ideas
Description: Speakers: Brant Houston, MaryJo Webster - *Moderated by Brant Houston, University of Illinois and MaryJo Webster, USA TODAY | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1723/

Subject: Let’s find the open and unsecured
Description: Speakers: Espen Sandli - This session will detail the story of how two journalist for the first time physically tested the data security in an entire country - the creepy and dangerous reality. Imagine being able to control your neighbor's webcam, open your competitor's database or take control of vital control systems with a few keystrokes. The Norwegian newspaper Dagbladet did just that. Here we will reveal how easily this can be done – even for amateurs. Come to this session and learn how you, without any knowledge, can detect and locate unsecured devices connected to the Internet in your country or state. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1726/

Subject: Make the command line work for you
Description: Speakers: Liz Lucas | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1621/

Subject: Building better maps with Leaflet, Mapbox and Javascript
Description: Speakers: Ashlyn Still | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1689/

Subject: Investigating business with data
Description: Speakers: John Schoen, Andrea Fuller - Businesses raise and spend trillions of dollars, build and tear down property, file for patents and copyrights, set up complex partnerships, sue and get sued, and otherwise file reams of documents every year. With all that activity, they leave plenty of marks for journalists to follow. Take your stories beyond the usual sources and learn how to dig through data for business investigations. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1696/

Subject: Tell me a story I won't forget
Description: Speakers: TBA | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1722/

Subject: Broadcast: Viz, quick hits and the data you need
Description: Speakers: Jamie Grey, Andy Pierrotti, Tisha Thompson, Matt Goldberg - *Moderated by Matt Goldberg, KNBC-Los Angeles | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1725/

Subject: Stats: Logistic regression
Description: Speakers: David Donald | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1615/

Subject: Regular expressions for beginners
Description: Speakers: Abraham Hyatt - Regular expressions are a powerful and compact way to slice, dice and clean up dirty data. They may look intimidating, but they're a must-know skill for anyone who works with data. We'll learn the fundamentals of regex and look at some real-world examples you can use when you get home. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1637/

Subject: Github 101: The basics
Description: Speakers: Jessica Lord, Anna Wiener - GitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. At its core, GitHub is a source-code host, but the platform can be used for sharing and collaborating on anything from government data to prose. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1622/

Subject: The new ecosystem of health care data
Description: Speakers: Dan Keating, Charles Ornstein, Meghan Hoyer - The world of health data is changing rapidly, with the release of huge data sets by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services and the Food and Drug Administration. This session will provide an introduction to this data, along with story ideas about how to mine it and create news apps that help customize the information for your audience. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1727/

Subject: The year in CAR
Description: Speakers: Megan Luther, Alex Richards - What were the big stories of the year? What were the most creative uses of data analysis? See what your colleagues have been up to and pick up some story ideas at the same time. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1729/

Subject: Bridging the developer/journalist gap
Description: Speakers: Anthony DeBarros, Maureen Linke, Chrys Wu - What are the values that drive coders and non-coders in news organizations? How can we bring these sometimes disparate tribes together to serve our common goal -- telling great stories? | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1730/

Subject: Moonshining: Indexes pack high-proof explanatory power
Description: Speakers: Paul Overberg - Distilling a mess of data gives it extra kick and smooths its way across the user's palate. Learn how to calculate a dozen indexes useful in local journalism. Also: When to adapt an index or even consider crafting your own. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1731/

Subject: Amazon cloud basics
Description: Speakers: Scott Klein | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1625/

Subject: Build your first news app *pre-registered attendees only
Description: Speakers: Ben Welsh, Derek Willis - This mini-boot camp will walk you through the process of building a simple, useful online news application from a dataset. You will get hands-on experience in every stage of the development process, writing Python, HTML and JavaScript using version control tools. You won't stop until you've deployed a working application onto the World Wide Web. Preregistration is required and seating is limited. Sessions will be held on Friday and Saturday morning. Laptops will be provided for the training. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1601/

Subject: Useful command line tools for reporters
Description: Speakers: Matt Kiefer - Get the most out of your Windows computer by leveraging the command line. We'll introduce the terminal and use it to do basic data transformation and analysis with Python, SQL and other tools./p> | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1639/

Subject: Fusion Tables for beginners
Description: Speakers: Kate Martin | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1631/

Subject: VR for the NICAR world: Immersive data
Description: Speakers: Robert Hernandez | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1720/

Subject: Getting started in Excel
Description: Speakers: Helena Bengtsson | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1634/

Subject: Map like a pro with ArcGIS Online
Description: Speakers: Brian Peterson, Robby Deming - We all live in a realm of data. But sometimes, spreadsheets and databases aren't the best way to tell your story. Take a hands-on tour of the redesigned ArcGIS Online to see how you can easily create intelligent maps in minutes. Learn how the new Smart Mapping feature in ArcGIS Online can help you investigate patterns in your data and easily create beautiful data visualizations, even if you've never worked with maps or GIS before. If you can use an Internet browser, you can create award-winning maps. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1629/

Subject: Visual journalism for tiny news desks
Description: Speakers: Kaeti Hinck, Jaeah Lee, Aaron Williams | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1732/

Subject: Thinking about interactivity
Description: Speakers: Mariana Santos, Robert Hernandez - *Moderated by Robert Hernandez, University of Southern California-Annenberg | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1733/

Subject: Watchdogging public spending
Description: Speakers: Joanna Lin, Mike Maciag, Cezary Podkul, Nicole Vap - *Moderated by Nicole Vap, KUSA/9News Denver | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1734/

Subject: Introducing Geomancer: Don’t let your data be lonely tonight
Description: Speakers: Derek Eder, Troy Thibodeaux, Serdar Tumgoren | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1736/

Subject: Red alert: Tools to automatically generate story leads
Description: Speakers: Abe Handler, Thomas Thoren, Todd Wallack - We'll give you ideas how to use technology to automatically check court records, financial filings, property sales, government contracts, news feeds and other websites for news. We will show off several easy-to-use tools, like Google Alerts and RSS readers, to monitor news feeds. And we'll talk about how to write your own custom programs to check records and generate story leads. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1735/

Subject: How I learned to take command of the command line: A journalist's guide to getting started
Description: Speakers: Chris Keller, AJ Vicens - This hands-on session aims to help command line novices learn some basic commands that can help them every day, including navigating through directories, creating files and tools to look at and work with structured data. If you're familiar with grep and curl this will likely be review. We'll end by highlighting some command line libraries that are musts for reporters. and provide additional resources so participants can go deeper on their own. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1623/

Subject: Getting started with Python
Description: Speakers: Jackie Kazil | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1795/

Subject: Making timelines
Description: Speakers: Lena Groeger - Displaying a series of events can be as simple as drawing a straight line. But if you want to get fancier, there are a bunch of other options to display chronologies and storylines. In this talk, we'll take a tour of current timelines in the wild and walk you through three open-source tools to help you make your own: ProPublica's TimelineSetter, Zach Wise's TimelineJS, and WNYC's Vertical Timeline. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1628/

Subject: First steps with R (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Annie Waldman - Take your first steps with powerful, open-source statistical language R by learning some of the basic skills you need to get up and running with R. By the end of this session, you will be able to take raw data, import it into R, and start your analysis. Topics that will be covered include: basic data importing, working with directories, reading in data, installing packages, as well as how to clean, explore and sort data. We'll also talk about how to find help when you're stuck. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1632/

Subject: Data alchemy
Description: Speakers: Mike Tigas, Jeremy B. Merrill, Eric Sagara - Ever get a load of PDF files back when you wanted data? Ever download shapefiles in esoteric projections? Encoding issues? This hands-on workshop will teach data-savvy users how they can get usable, analyzable data out of what would otherwise be considered junk (or a headache). | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1794/

Subject: Using formulas in Excel
Description: Speakers: John Schoen | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1635/

Subject: Crowdsourcing with Google Forms
Description: Speakers: Doug Haddix - Learn how to create a simple Web-based form to gather information and save it in a Google spreadsheet. No programming skills needed. Journalists can use Google Forms to crowdsource data, story tips, polls, and other information from readers and viewers. In addition, Google Forms can be used internally as a collaborative tool to collect information and data from everyone involved in a news story. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1626/

Subject: Introduction to web programming
Description: Speakers: Peggy Bustamante | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1630/

Subject: Github 101: The basics (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Jessica Lord, Anna Wiener - GitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. At its core, GitHub is a source-code host, but the platform can be used for sharing and collaborating on anything from government data to prose. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1640/

Subject: Jobs and career straight-talk: For (and by) young'uns only
Description: Speakers: Jeremy B. Merrill, Sisi Wei - Have questions on how to break into the field or get a paid internship/job? Simple or impolitic ones that you couldn't ask a boss or hiring manager/editor? Questions about newsroom "culture" or the tacit knowledge required to network or interview for a job? Sisi Wei and Jeremy Merrill, both less than four years out of undergrad, will be giving students and early-career journalists any knowledge and job-seeking advice they need to help them become designer/developer/data journalists. We'll also pair you up with other young, employed grads for a few rounds of speed Q&A so you can get different perspectives and a chance to ask questions in in a small group or one-on-one. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1740/

Subject: Local data that can lead to stories
Description: Speakers: Walker Moskop, Lee Zurik, Gavin Off | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1738/

Subject: Color (and shape and place) my world
Description: Speakers: Jim Herries, Robert Simmon | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1737/

Subject: Grabbing data from websites without scraping (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Scott Klein, Michelle Minkoff | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1812/

Subject: Demo: Tools for cracking PDFs
Description: Speakers: Miguel Barbosa, Kevin Crowe - So much data comes to us in .pdf form or, worse, on paper that we then need to scan. We'll offer tips, tricks and best practices to quickly crack open those dastardly files and get the data in a usable format. We'll look at some of classic methods of breaking down PDFs and we'll discuss docHive and Tabula, tools developed by fellow NICARians that can help liberate data. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1741/

Subject: Machine learning in the wild -- #wins and #fails
Description: Speakers: Sarah Cohen, Steven Rich, Janet Roberts - For several years, machine learning has been a tantalizing Siren for reporters, promising to sort through your documents and find the juicy ones, or providing a road map to the people and places in your collection. After a few experiments in the wild, we'll help separate myth from truth, unpack the confusing language of the discipline and provide tips about when it might, and might not, serve your stories. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1739/

Subject: Simple stats in Excel
Description: Speakers: Olga Pierce - You don't need a special statistics program to run simple statistics. In this session, you'll learn how to compute some basic statistics in Excel and figure out what they mean. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1638/

Subject: PivotTables in Excel
Description: Speakers: Jonathan Stoneman | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1636/

Subject: Visualizing your data with R
Description: Speakers: Ronald Campbell | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1633/

Subject: Web scraping using Python
Description: Speakers: Paul Schreiber | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1624/

Subject: Stat-a-thon
Description: Speakers: Agustin Armendariz, David Donald, Holly Hacker, Dan Keating, Sharon Machlis, Jennifer LaFleur - *Moderated by Jennifer LaFleur, The Center for Investigative Reporting | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1744/

Subject: Mapbox
Description: Speakers: Sarah Frostenson | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1796/

Subject: Teach yourself to code
Description: Speakers: Becca Aaronson - When you don't know anything about learning to code, it can seem like a daunting task. Fortunately, the Internet is stock-full of examples and answers to help you. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1643/

Subject: Intro to D3
Description: Speakers: Christopher Canipe, Jon McClure - Learn the basics of using D3 to make customized, elegant data visualizations. This JavaScript library gives you the power to draw online by harnessing the power of SVGs. We'll explain what makes D3 so great and demonstrate a step-by-step guide for making a chart that you can put to work in your own newsroom. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1798/

Subject: Advanced Django for data analysis
Description: Speakers: Armand Emamdjomeh, Anthony Pesce | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1641/

Subject: Getting started with JavaScript
Description: Speakers: Andy Boyle - In this workshop, you'll learn not only basic JavaScript fundamentals, but some larger programming fundamentals, too. You'll learn about variables, if/else logic, functions and more. You'll also learn about JavaScript programming shortcuts using JavaScript libraries, such as jQuery. You'll also be shown examples of projects built using JavaScript, so you'll know what is possible. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1645/

Subject: Getting data into Excel
Description: Speakers: Patti DiVincenzo | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1648/

Subject: Mini Boot Camp *pre-registered attendees only
Description: Speakers: Megan Luther, Jaimi Dowdell - Kickstart your data skills with IRE's original mini-boot camp.  This series of hands-on classes will introduce you to spreadsheets and databases with IRE's proven techniques. IRE's experienced trainers will walk you through sorting, calculating and interviewing data.  You'll come away with a solid base for using data analysis in your own newsroom. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1603/

Subject: Using data to detect environmental dangers
Description: Speakers: Caelainn Barr, Michael Corey, Robert Gebeloff, Ingrid Lobet - *Moderated by Ingrid Lobet, independent journalist | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1742/

Subject: Life after Excel and Access - the next steps in data journalism
Description: Speakers: Helena Bengtsson, Ryann Grochowski Jones, Eric Sagara - This panel features several data experts from traditional beat reporting backgrounds who will talk about their professional development experiences. What was their next steps after learning the basics of data reporting? How did they discover and learn new tools? How can reporters lobby in their newsrooms for time to learn new tools? | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1745/

Subject: Scraping, APIs and data extraction
Description: Speakers: Cedric Sam, Nils Mulvad | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1746/

Subject: Critical questions to ask of studies, press releases and scientific reports
Description: Speakers: Peter Aldhous, Ronald Campbell, Pat Thomas - Confused by p values and effect sizes? Unsure about what peer review really means? Reluctant to challenge Dr. Famous with potentially insulting questions? We'll provide tips for using expert sources, documentary research and common sense to separate the scientific wheat from the chaff. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1743/

Subject: GitHub 201: Leveling up with the command line
Description: Speakers: Jessica Lord, Anna Wiener - This workshop is for people who are already familiar with GitHub and version control, and want to dive a little deeper. We'll cover how to use Git on the command line, how the GitHub Flow supports team collaboration and deployments, and overall best practices. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1644/

Subject: Playing with Arduino
Description: Speakers: John Keefe - Learn how to make simple, interactive projects using Arduino hardware. We'll walk through a couple of easy projects to give you a feel for what's possible. Open to anyone who likes to play and make things blink. We'll have a few Arduinos on hand to share, or you can bring your own. (The parts we'll be using are right here and cost less than $30.) We won't be soldering and no previous coding experience required. Bring a laptop if you can. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1649/

Subject: Useful command line tools for reporters (repeat)
Description: Speakers: Agustin Armendariz, Kendall Taggart - Ever had a CSV file too large to open in Excel?  Ever had one so big it crashed your computer? We’ll show you some simple tricks for wrangling data on the command line. If you've never programmed before but frequently use Excel and SQL, this class will make your life better. Bonus: We’ll show you how to make your Mac recite poetry for you. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1642/

Subject: Spotlight: Using abstraction to gain knowledge from numbers
Description: Speakers: Robert Simmon | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1750/

Subject: Free tools
Description: Speakers: Alex Richards, Marco Tulio Pires, Natalia Mazotte - A breathless tour of the universe of free software that's available to help import, summarize, manage, graph and map your data. From statistical analysis in R and Python to geospatial analysis in QGIS, PostGIS, and Spatialite, we've got the tools for you. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1749/

Subject: Data behind the news
Description: Speakers: TBA | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1748/

Subject: Deep dives part 2
Description: Speakers: John Bones - *Moderated by John Bones, Verdens Gang | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1747/

Subject: Risk adjustment basics
Description: Speakers: Olga Pierce - You're doing a story about a doctor with a high mortality rate. Is she a bad doctor or does she take the sickest patients? Or you're doing a story about a school with low test scores. Is it a bad school or does it have the hardest to teach students? How can you tell? The answer is risk adjustment. We'll show you how to use logistic regression and risk indices to make sure you're comparing apples to apples. Even if you never run a risk adjustment yourself, you'll learn how academics and government agencies risk adjust the data they release. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1751/

Subject: Kimono: An easier way to scrape the Web
Description: Speakers: Shri Ganeshram | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1797/

Subject: Analyzing networks with Gephi
Description: Speakers: Peter Aldhous - Gephi is an open source platform for network analysis (aka social network analysis), allowing you to produce publication-quality vector graphics and to export your analyses for interactive online visualization. You'll learn how to use the software by turning data on voting patterns in the US Senate into an informative graphic revealing the chamber's underlying dynamics -- and highlighting the few senators who broke the partisan mold. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1647/

Subject: Mapping JS: Building narrative with geo data + CartoDB
Description: Speakers: Aurelia Moser - Learn how to publish stylish interactive maps in javascript. We'll bridge from the Intermediate Javascript course and talk about how to apply JS skills to mapping visualizations. We'll cover some basics, data management, particulars of CartoJS and then some tools for designing narrative around maps. Below is a rough outline of the class. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1646/

Subject: Lightning Talks (Sponsored by the Knight Foundation)
Description: Speakers: Sisi Wei - *Moderated by Sisi Wei, ProPublica | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1752/

Subject: Philip Meyer Award Reception
Description: Join fellow CAR attendees in celebrating the Philip Meyer Award Winners at a reception Friday night with light hor d' oeuvres and a cash bar beginning at 5:45 p.m. in Marquis Ballroom C-D.  | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1753/

Subject: Build your first news app (Saturday) *pre-registered attendees only
Description: Speakers: Ben Welsh, Derek Willis - This is a continuation of Friday's hands-on workshop.  Preregistered attendees only. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1602/

Subject: Defense against the dark arts: Security for you and your sources
Description: Speakers: Jeff Larson, Mike Tigas - Keeping your communications with sources secure is a vital part of your job as a journalist. But it's hard to know where to start and most of us don't have time to learn secure software well enough to trust it. We'll show you what you can do to secure yourself even if you have only a minute, or 10 minutes, and point you to further resources. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1758/

Subject: Getting it the rightest you can
Description: Speakers: Jennifer LaFleur, Thomas Hargrove, John Perry, Janet Roberts - *Moderated by Jennifer LaFleur, The Center for Investigative Reporting | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1757/

Subject: Design/Viz: What to do, and what not to do
Description: Speakers: Anna Flagg, Lena Groeger, Moiz Syed - Good design helps maximize your story's impact by increasing its usability and comprehension. This session covers the basic user experience dos and don'ts for online journalism. We'll include plenty of examples of good and bad design from leading journalism outlets. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1756/

Subject: Advanced Fusion Tables
Description: Speakers: Daniel Lathrop | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1656/

Subject: Do more in R with these useful new packages
Description: Speakers: Sharon Machlis - From interactive graphics and maps to data wrangling in a snap, new packages such as dplyr and dygraphs for R make it fast and easy to perform powerful data visualization & analysis. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1657/

Subject: More MySQL: Learn to use the command line and other powerful features
Description: Speakers: Agustin Armendariz | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1663/

Subject: Excel magic (advanced functions) *repeat session
Description: Speakers: MaryJo Webster - Learn about various tools and functions in Excel that come in handy when you need to re-structure or otherwise get your data ready for analysis. We'll cover string functions, logical functions, date functions, the Tableau Reshaper, merging data using lookup functions and perhaps a few other nifty tricks if time allows. This is a fast-paced class intended to introduce you to these tools, not master them. But you'll walk out with practice data and a 20-page tipsheet that covers in detail everything we do in class, plus other great Excel tips. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1690/

Subject: Create your own interactive newsgame without coding
Description: Speakers: TBA | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1664/

Subject: Twitter tricks and analytics (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Doug Haddix - If you know the basics of Twitter, you're ready to ratchet up your skills. This hands-on session will take you to the next level: advanced Twitter searches, mining tweets by location, creative uses of Twitter lists (public and private), and apps/services that provide robust analytics. The payoff: better sources (particularly during breaking news) and a competitive edge in your market. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1653/

Subject: Processes, standards and documentation for data-driven projects
Description: Speakers: Christopher Groskopf, Paul Overberg - Making news is hard, but it can be impossible without a process to support it. We'll discuss how we use team standards, documentation and consistent process to produce polished work on deadline. We'll cover cases where a team builds one thing – like a documentary or app – and when a team builds many things – like a document- or data-sharing project. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1755/

Subject: This just in: Data for breaking news investigations
Description: Speakers: Stephen Stock, Cheryl Phillips - What will you do the next time a plane crashes, a fire starts or a politician gets caught in a scandal? We'll show you how you can prepare for the next big story using dashboards, searchable databases and more. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1754/

Subject: Ruby 1: Introduction
Description: Speakers: Al Shaw | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1650/
Location: See printed schedule for room information

Subject: Tools for cracking PDFs
Description: Speakers: Danielle Cervantes | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1654/

Subject: Building mobile-ready visualizations and maps in minutes with Silk
Description: Speakers: Alex Salkever - Silk is an all-purpose tool for data journalism that lets anyone convert spreadsheets into an online database and data visualizations in minutes. In this demo session we'll pull data about 2015 killings by the police in California aggregated from Facebook and and turn it into maps, charts, and interactive tables. Then we'll upload data from the 500 most successful Kickstarter technology projects in 2014, do some quick visual analysis, then save and publish visualizations. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1763/

Subject: Municipal bonds 101
Description: Speakers: Cezary Podkul - Curious about covering your local and state and government borrowing but don't know how to get started? Join this hands-on session to get a technical overview of how to analyze bond offering statements: how to find them, what the numbers mean, how to identify the key terms and conditions and scale-up your reporting using public and private data sources. We will walk you through several offering statements and teach participants how to develop a basic framework for finding the data they need to track local borrowing. Topics covered will include: navigating the EMMA database, finding and reading official statements, using CUSIP identifiers to track debt, find credit ratings, ongoing disclosures, and calculating and benchmarking borrowing costs, and capital appreciation bonds (CABs). | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1665/

Subject: How to build a happy team
Description: Speakers: Becca Aaronson, Lauren Rabaino, Adam Schweigert, Trei Brundrett, Brian Boyer - *Moderated by Trei Brundrett, Vox Media | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1760/

Subject: Advanced Python for data analysis: Part 1
Description: Speakers: Travis Swicegood | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1799/

Subject: Social media sleuthing
Description: Speakers: Doug Haddix - Explore new apps and advanced searches to find experts and other sources for enterprise and breaking news stories. Discover how best to find people quickly on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and Instagram. Learn the best tricks for finding sources in a specific location (city, region, state or country). | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1762/

Subject: (Keep) following the money on state and local politics
Description: Speakers: Ben Wieder, Denise Malan, Edwin Bender, Ted Mellnik - *Moderated by Ben Wieder, The Center for Public Integrity | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1761/

Subject: Sensor journalism: Buzz or BS?
Description: Speakers: John Keefe, Travis Hartman, Amy Schmitz Weiss, Matthew Waite - The hype around Sensor Journalism is that it's a major new frontier in Data Journalism. So where are all the examples? Is it buzz or BS? We'll explore that, show some successes and unveil a few projects emerging from the lab. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1759/

Subject: Advanced SQL for analysis
Description: Speakers: Liz Lucas | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1662/

Subject: Text editing with Regular Expressions
Description: Speakers: Jon McClure - A saying goes, if you have a problem and think, "I know, I'll use Regular Expressions," you now have two problems. Come learn to wield the power of text pattern matching to transform data and shortcut complex cleaning tasks. Leave with an abiding dread of malicious search-and-replace and pick up some safe-handling practices to keep you from the pit of a regex gone bad. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1660/

Subject: R: Preplication
Description: Speakers: Bill Alpert | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1658/

Subject: Ruby 2: Acquiring and transforming data
Description: Speakers: Jeff Larson | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1651/

Subject: Import.io: Web scraping without coding (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Andrew Fogg - import.io allows you to convert data from the internet into a structured useable table. This data can then be used to analyze trends, build leads and build news stories. Extracting data gives you ultimate control. The class centers around extracting data from the web followed by manipulating and using that data. We will use import.io to gather the data and then use 3rd programs (Google Sheets and Excel) to manipulate and use the data. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1691/

Subject: OpenRefine (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: David Herzog | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1661/

Subject: Under pressure: Real life in real time with breaking news
Description: Speakers: Stephen Stock | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1659/

Subject: Advanced Python for data analysis: Part 2
Description: Speakers: Tom Meagher | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1800/

Subject: Machine learning
Description: Speakers: Chase Davis | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1666/

Subject: Ruby 3: Simple web apps with Ruby
Description: Speakers: Jacob Harris | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1652/

Subject: Deep dive: Phil Meyer Award winners
Description: Speakers: Phil Williams, David Donald, Ryan McNeill, Michael Grabell, Lena Groeger, Jeff Larson, Olga Pierce, Fred Schulte - *Moderated by Phil Williams, WTVF-Nashville | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1764/

Subject: Go home and share your work!
Description: A couple days at NICAR will fill your head with new skills and knowledge, the kinds of things that not only make you a better journalist, but can have a huge effect on colleagues when you get home. Sharing what you've learned makes your whole newsroom stronger, lets you identify new people to collaborate with, and even helps you internalize all those great ideas you've got right now. We'll talk through teaching strategies that have gotten results--from small-group conversations to internal hack days--and work together to figure out how you might apply them to the specific needs of your newsroom. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1765/

Subject: Amazon cloud basics (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Mike Tigas | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1801/

Subject: Intermediate/Advanced Security
Description: Speakers: Harlo Holmes, Aurelia Moser - In this workshop, Harlo Holmes (Guardian Project/OpenNews Alum) and Aurelia Moser (CartoDB/OpenNews Alum]) will go through the finer details of digital security with key management, software verification, 2-Factor Authentication, PGP, OTR chat, and encrypted file sharing; and guide you through some common rough spots. Please bring your laptops, and get ready to go beyond "hello world"! | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1768/

Subject: Policing the police
Description: Speakers: Rob Barry, Ben Poston, Topher Sanders, Corey Johnson - *Moderated by Corey Johnson, The Marshall Project | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1767/

Subject: Making data-informed design decisions
Description: Speakers: Tyler Fisher, Josh Kadis | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1766/

Subject: Data negotiation: To FOIA or not to FOIA
Description: Speakers: Mark Horvit, Michael Grabell, Paula Lavigne, Anupama Narayanswamy - *Moderated by Mark Horvit, IRE/NICAR | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1772/

Subject: Introduction to mapping: Importing and displaying data geographically with QGIS
Description: Speakers: Peter Aldhous - QGIS is the leading free, open source Geographic Information System (GIS) program. You'll learn how to use QGIS to make a simple thematic map, with areas colored according to data, plus a map of points scaled according to values in the data, how to set their map projections, and how to export them as a vector graphic. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1668/

Subject: Web scraping using Python (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Paul Schreiber | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1667/

Subject: Mini Boot Camp (Saturday) *pre-registered attendees only
Description: Speakers: Denise Malan, Liz Lucas - This is a continuation of Friday's hands-on workshop.  Preregistered attendees only. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1604/

Subject: So they bought a federal candidate, now what?
Description: Speakers: Ben Wieder, Jacob Fenton, Sarah Bryner, Christopher Schnaars - *Moderated by Ben Wieder, The Center for Public Integrity | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1769/

Subject: Catching fire: Spreading data journalism throughout the newsroom
Description: Speakers: Emma Carew Grovum, Jeff Ernsthausen, Jodi Upton | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1770/

Subject: Spotlight: Talking about uncertainty
Description: Speakers: Jordan Ellenberg | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1771/

Subject: How to draw the Internet: Better interactives through paper prototyping
Description: Speakers: Noah Veltman, Sisi Wei - Writing code is hard. Drawing is easy. In this session, we'll teach you how to use paper prototypes to design an effective interactive. Refining ideas on paper gets you important feedback at the start of a project, before you've painted yourself into a corner with a wrong approach. We'll practice thinking like a computer without using one -- with better, more meaningful results to show for it. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1773/

Subject: Getting started with Python (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Ryan Nagle, Marcos Vanetta, Aaron Williams | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1802/

Subject: Getting started with SQLite
Description: Speakers: Troy Thibodeaux | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1669/

Subject: Automate your development life: Build and deploy with Yeoman and Grunt
Description: Speakers: Ryan Murphy | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1670/

Subject: Twitter Bootstrap: Responsive website framework
Description: Speakers: Erika Lee | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1671/

Subject: Getting started with machine learning
Description: Speakers: Chase Davis, Jeff Ernsthausen, Robert Lannon - You don't need a PhD to get started with machine learning. Learn about creative ways machine learning and other statistical modeling techniques have been used to solve unique problems in three different newsrooms. We'll cover several examples and leave plenty of time for questions. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1774/

Subject: Mapping 2: Manipulating and editing geographic data with QGIS
Description: Speakers: Michael Corey - QGIS is a powerful tool for processing data for use by other mapping applications, including for web mapping. In this class you'll learn how to join tables of data to existing shapefiles and how to save data in formats commonly used for web mapping. You'll also learn how to edit geographic data, and how to process data consisting of hundreds or thousands of points to give a more meaningful summary display. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1673/

Subject: Flying solo: When your data “team” is just you
Description: Speakers: Kate Martin, Scott Pham, Chad Skelton, Brent Jones - *Moderated by Brent Jones, St. Louis Public Radio | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1777/

Subject: Reporting and presentation with DocumentCloud
Description: Speakers: Anthony DeBarros, Ted Han - Get to know the suite of tools that DocumentCloud offers to help you better organize, analyze and present public documents. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1675/

Subject: Python 2
Description: Speakers: Ryan Nagle, Marcos Vanetta, Aaron Williams | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1803/

Subject: 50 ideas in 60 minutes
Description: Speakers: Tyler Dukes, Mc Nelly Torres - If you have a few data skills and you're looking for the right ideas to try them out, here are plenty -- whether you need something for tomorrow or you have a few weeks. We've got 50 proven winners for media outlets of all sizes, coming at you fast! | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1776/

Subject: Data smells
Description: Speakers: Jacob Harris, Chris Keller, Aurelia Moser - In the world of software development, "data smells" is a term for those telltale signs that indicate bad software needs to be refactored. As data journalists, we encounter common types of data smells in the data we work with on every project. It's time to get organized. In this panel, let's refine a site we've prototyped to collect and categorize these data smells. We're not building a site here, but we should leave this panel with a clear idea of what the features of a data smells compendium would be. A wiki seems like an obvious choice, but how does an entry look? How do we organize and collect these smells? What can we do to automate the tedious process of vetting a data set? We'll explore these questions. The session will begin with a basic exploration of the concept of data smells. From there we will discuss several questions about how to build a site for cataloguing data smells: * How do we document data smells? * Where do we host this site? * What are all the points in the reporting process where errors occur? * Checklists? Can we automate smell checks? * Can we bundle smells for common types of data into guides? * Can we make the data smells idea approachable for readers? | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1775/

Subject: Visualization for reporting
Description: Speakers: Coulter Jones, Michelle Minkoff | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1778/

Subject: Teach yourself to code (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Becca Aaronson - When you don't know anything about learning to code, it can seem like a daunting task. Fortunately, the Internet is stock-full of examples and answers to help you. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1672/

Subject: Visualizing your data with R (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Ronald Campbell | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1676/

Subject: Simple stats in Excel (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Norm Lewis - You don't need a special statistics program to run simple statistics. In this session, you'll learn how to compute some basic statistics in Excel and figure out what they mean. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1680/

Subject: On repeat: How to use loops to explain anything
Description: Speakers: Lena Groeger - From animated gifs illustrating how a car engine works to looping interactives demonstrating sampling error, we're seeing more and more ways of presenting ideas, explaining processes, and just capturing small moments in endless, repeating sequences. We'll take a look at why loops work so well as explanatory tools, how they've been used in the newsroom, and how you can create your very own. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1783/

Subject: Intro to D3 (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Darla Cameron, Alex Bordens - Learn the basics of using D3 to make customized, elegant data visualizations. This JavaScript library gives you the power to draw online by harnessing the power of SVGs. We'll explain what makes D3 so great and demonstrate a step-by-step guide for making a chart that you can put to work in your own newsroom. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1677/

Subject: Web inspector for complex scrapes
Description: Speakers: Eric Sagara - M102 | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1678/

Subject: Editing the data story
Description: Speakers: David Armstrong, Joel Engelhardt, Shawn McIntosh, John Walton - *Moderated by David Armstrong, Georgia News Lab | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1779/

Subject: Joining and advanced operations in SQLite
Description: Speakers: Matt Kiefer | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1679/

Subject: Python 3
Description: Speakers: Ryan Nagle, Marcos Vanetta, Aaron Williams | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1804/

Subject: How to not make a fool of yourself with statistics
Description: Speakers: Rob Barry, Holly Hacker, Jaxk Reeves, John Perry - *Moderated by John Perry, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1782/

Subject: Mise en Place: What a restaurant kitchen can teach us about deadline coding
Description: Speakers: Jeremy Bowers - *Moderated by Jeremy Bowers, The New York Times | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1781/

Subject: Reporting out the data story
Description: Speakers: Steve Myers, Andrew Lehren, James Ball, Kendall Taggart - *Moderated by Steve Myers, The Lens | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1780/

Subject: Shedding light on the dark web: Using tech to build corporate investigations
Description: Speakers: David Buxton, Sam Hardy - Normal search engines only reach 10% of the data available online. How do investigative journalists go beyond Google and find the kind of corporate information hidden in the dark web that can break a story wide open? Through real examples from 2014, including the successful investigation of a massive $11 billion tax fraud in Ukraine, the Arachnys team will highlight how snippets of corporate data can be knitted together to create major corruption scoops. They will also demo the Arachnys research platform and show how it supports organisations such as the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ), FirstLook Media and Intelligence Online to build investigations. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1788/

Subject: Excel en Español
Description: Speakers: Kevin Crowe, Jeff Kelly Lowenstein, Lucio Villa - This three-hour hands-on workshop teaches journalists, in Spanish, how to use Excel, a powerful electronic spreadsheet for deadline and beat reporting on budgets, salaries, elections and more. Learn from fluent teachers how to dig deeper using the Internet and find valuable datasets for your stories. Seating is limited. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1808/

Subject: OpenElections hackathon
Description: The OpenElections team will be tackling Georgia election results at NICAR this year, and we're looking for coders as well as anyone interested in helping out, and spending a few hours with our team. Here's how you can be involved: | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1811/

Subject: The best of broadcast investigations 2014
Description: Speakers: Mark Horvit - *Moderated by Mark Horvit, IRE/NICAR | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1810/

Subject: Just enough Django: Distributed data entry in the newsroom (pre-registered attendees only)
Description: Speakers: Ken Schwencke, Ben Welsh - Ben Welsh presents a step-by-step guide to creating a simple web application that empowers you to enlist reporters in data entry and refinement. The 3-hour, hands-on tutorial will teach you how to take advantage of the Django Web framework's powerful administration panel, without bothering with all the other web developer crap. You will learn how to design database tables, load in data and quickly create a system for others to improve it. Preregistration is required and seating is limited. Laptops will be provided for the training. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1606/

Subject: Advanced SQL using PostgreSQL
Description: Speakers: Anthony DeBarros - Using PostgreSQL and the pgAdmin interface, we will explore advanced SQL techniques to interview and clean data, go from basic math to advanced stats, and create ranks and rates. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1687/

Subject: Installation party
Description: Many conference sessions cover tools and applications that are open source and available to journalists for free. During this session we invite you to bring your laptop and we'll help you get set up with the tools you've heard about and are itching to try out. We will rely on volunteers to help out, so what you're able to  install and how long it takes will depend on demand. Remember also that you must have administrative privileges on your machine; if you're blocked from these privileges, we won't be able to override that. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1683/

Subject: Lightning fast data analysis with Tableau: Part one
Description: Speakers: Sarah Ryley, Jewel Loree - Tableau is a powerful tool for data analysis that queries your data using a visual interface, with the ability to merge multiple datasets totaling millions of rows -- and it's free for IRE members. This session will teach you how to reshape and analyze pesky nested spreadsheets, join tables, group and filter dimensions, and do some basic calculations such as percent change and rate -- all by simply dragging, dropping and clicking your mouse (okay, and a little typing). You'll save hours of work not having to type out long, complicated SQL statements. This session will be using Tableau's newest release for Macs. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1681/

Subject: Introduction to mapping: Importing and displaying data geographically with QGIS (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Alex Richards - QGIS is the leading free, open source Geographic Information System (GIS) program. You'll learn how to use QGIS to make a simple thematic map, with areas colored according to data, plus a map of points scaled according to values in the data, how to set their map projections, and how to export them as a vector graphic. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1692/

Subject: Mini Boot Camp (Sunday) *pre-registered attendees only
Description: Speakers: David Herzog, Denise Malan - This is a continuation of Saturday's hands-on workshop.  Preregistered attendees only. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1605/

Subject: Tools for cracking PDFs (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Danielle Cervantes | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1807/

Subject: Game of life: Data from day one to the day you die
Description: Speakers: Jaimi Dowdell, Jennifer LaFleur | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1785/

Subject: Finding data trails
Description: Speakers: Megan Luther | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1786/

Subject: Lightning fast data analysis with Tableau: Part two
Description: Speakers: Ben Jones, Sarah Ryley - This session will use some of the tools covered in the first data analysis with Tableau session, and go deeper with more complex calculated fields, parameters and regression analyses. We'll end with a freestyle session – you'll call out the problem and we'll show you how to solve it. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1682/

Subject: Under pressure: Real life in real time with breaking news (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Stephen Stock | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1684/

Subject: Mapping 2: Manipulating and editing geographic data with QGIS (repeat session)
Description: Speakers: Alex Richards - QGIS is a powerful tool for processing data for use by other mapping applications, including for web mapping. In this class you'll learn how to join tables of data to existing shapefiles and how to save data in formats commonly used for web mapping. You'll also learn how to edit geographic data, and how to process data consisting of hundreds or thousands of points to give a more meaningful summary display. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1693/

Subject: Using Silk.co to analyze data and publish beautiful maps and charts in minutes
Description: Speakers: Alex Salkever - Silk is an all-purpose tool for data journalism that anyone can start using immediately, without training or tech skills. Starting from a simple spreadsheet, Silk allows anyone to quickly generate data insights and build publish-ready, mobile-friendly data visualizations. In this hands-on session, you'll analyze upload a spreadsheet of Kickstarter project results and analyze the data to find stories. If time permits, we'll also convert a spreadsheet of crowdsourced data on 2014 deadly police shootings in California into Silk visualizations and publish those on a blog. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1806/

Subject: Making your own Yo bot
Description: Speakers: Matthew Waite - Heard about Sensor Journalism and want to get your hands dirty? We've got a handful of devices and some sensors. Come learn how to combine the physical world and the Internet by making a bot that says Yo. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1686/

Subject: Using machine learning to deal with dirty data: a Dedupe demonstration
Description: Speakers: Jeff Ernsthausen, Derek Eder, Eric van Zanten - Tired of popping the same data set into OpenRefine every time you want to answer basic questions like “who gave the most money to politicians in Idaho this year?” Sure you are. We all are. Then come see a demonstration of Dedupe, a tool that uses machine learning to identify unique individuals, organizations and other entities in the kinds of messy datasets that journalists encounter the most. We’ll go over the basics of how the tool works and give a demonstration of how to use it to find the unique entities in your datasets. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1790/

Subject: Mining searchable databases for stories
Description: Speakers: Jonathan Stoneman, Jaimi Dowdell | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1787/

Subject: Take home a text editor
Description: Speakers: Liz Lucas - At some point during the conference, in at least one hands-on session, you will probably use a text editor: Notepad++ or Sublime Text, for example. You might ask: What exactly is a text editor and why does everyone use them? In this session we’ll talk about why you should have a good text editor and what they can do for you that other programs (such as Word) can’t. We’ll talk about which ones are the best, and since most are free and easily to install, by the end of the session you will be ready (and eager) to take one home! | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1685/

Subject: CAR wash
Description: Speakers: Sean Sposito | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1688/

Subject: Advanced DocumentCloud: Examples and suggestions
Description: Speakers: Anthony DeBarros, Ted Han - Take a deeper dive into DocumentCloud and its API and bring your ideas for features you'd like to see in the platform. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1789/

Subject: Career roundtable
Description: Wondering what you need to learn to take that next step in your career? Interested in which skills news organizations are prioritizing now, and what might set you up for what they'll want next? Drop by and join us for a discussion of the skills that will help you progress. | URL: http://ire.org/events-and-training/event/1494/1784/
